awd_titl_txt: Research Initiation Award: Physical forces impacting the temporal variability of mesopelagic prey at the Cape Hatteras marine top-predator diversity hotspot
awd_abstract_narration:
The Historically Black Colleges and Universities-Undergraduate Program (HBCU-UP) Research Initiation Awards (RIAs) provide support to STEM junior faculty at HBCUs who are starting to build a research program, as well as for mid-career faculty who may have returned to the faculty ranks after holding an administrative post or who need to redirect and rebuild a research program. Faculty members may pursue research at their home institution, at an NSF-funded Center, at a research intensive institution or at a national laboratory. The RIA projects are expected to help further the faculty member's research capability and effectiveness, to improve research and teaching at his or her home institution, and to involve undergraduate students in research experiences. With support from the National Science Foundation, Savannah State University (SSU) will conduct research aimed at understanding the influence of physical dynamics on the mesopelagic community structure and its role in top predator ecology. This project will be used to enhance teaching and learning at SSU and thus, is geared for increasing marketable quantitative skills in undergraduate education and for preparing our diverse undergraduates for graduate school or the job market. The research and educational efforts will contribute to the mission of SSU's College of Sciences and Technology (COST) to "delivering high quality education, scholarship, and research in STEM" by expanding its existing research capacity. In addition, by providing the opportunities for undergraduates to participate in cutting-edge oceanographic research and gain mentorship in advanced oceanographic data methods, this project addresses the need to equip a diverse student population for the next generation of geosciences, particularly with the research and quantitative skills that will be in greatest demand in the coming years/decades.


The goal of the proposed study is to understand the relationships among the oceanography of the mesopelagic community and marine mammal top predators. The specific aims of this project are to: 1) describe the temporal variability of the physical oceanography of the region; 2) describe the temporal variability in the mesopelagic community; and 3) determine temporal linkages among the physical oceanographic setting, mesopelagic prey field, and vocalizing deep-diving marine mammals. This project will result in the application of sensors in a novel way, providing an example of the application and design of multi-sensor mooring package specifically targeted for the measurements of complex ecosystem interactions ranging from the physical habitat and the mesopelagic prey community all the way to apex predators. The findings from this study will provide a great step towards improving the study of marine top predators and their prey, whose focus is shifting from distribution and abundance to ecosystem interactions. This project will be conducted in collaboration with Duke University.

por.por_cntn:
The mesopelagic community is one of the most ecologically important prey resources in the ocean, yet is a very under-studied community due to the difficulty to make measurements in the middle depths of the ocean from typical oceanographic research platforms from the surface or seafloor. The goal of this project was to improve our understanding of the role of the physical ocean dynamics from Gulf Stream variability on the availability of mesopelagic prey layers to predators like deep-diving marine mammals who feed within these layers or on prey supported by them. Data collected from a novel bio-physical mooring was deployed over the continental slope near Cape Hatteras, North Carolina over a 1 year period in 2016-2017. Physical oceanographic instruments were combined with bioacoustics echosounders and placed on the mooring package mid-water with instruments oriented both upward and downward in order to sample throughout the entire water column. Analysis of these measurements revealed a seasonal pattern in the depth of the daytime scattering layer (between 400-600m) of the mesopelagic community with the main scattering layer, descending deeper in the summer months, presumably due to increasing light levels. There was also seasonality in physical forcing evidenced by the dominant orientation of current velocity in the upper waters flowing to the northeast down to about 500 m. Reversals in mid-water current velocity occurred frequently from the passing of Gulf Stream frontal eddies and were associated with a significant enhancement in the acoustic abundance of the scattering community, but these were also associated with a deepening of the layers. The strongest correlation of water column-integrated acoustic backscatter was present with the hydrographic variables, temperature, salinity, and density, and a weak correlation was present with alongshore and cross-shore current velocity.

This research demonstrated the capacity for extended physical and biological datasets from mid-water and whole-water column community from a highly dynamic environment like the Gulf Stream off Cape Hatteras. Understanding the interactions between the mesopelagic community and the physical oceanography is critical for understanding how foraging predators use these resources. Self-contained echosounders on mid-water mooring packages were shown to be a successful tool for investigating the mesopelagic community, even in the highly dynamic Gulf Stream habitat.

This project provided training and mentoring to 13 undergraduate students at SSU over 4 years, with most of them coming from under-represented groups (9 women and 8 minorities). Student interns received training in bioacoustics instrumentation, data analysis methods, and biological oceanography. Of those students, at least 5 have gone on to graduate programs. A total of 11 presentations were conducted at national/international scientific conferences, including 10 presentations with the first author as one of these student interns. This project also supported the PI and interns to participate in outreach events to 3 local elementary and middle school classrooms and Coast camp, a summer program for local K-12 students at SSU. Three of the project interns were involved in helping to develop interactive learning activities focused on marine bioacoustics, food webs, and oceanographic data analysis methods that were presented during K-12 classroom visits. Finally, data from this project have enhanced two data methods courses taught by the PI in both the undergraduate and graduate programs in Marine Science at SSU by providing a variety of integrative physical and bio-acoustic data types to foster training in a high-demand areas of geosciences.
